project.teaser: There is a clear gap in the adoption of paediatric healthcare innovations which continues to hinder the access to such innovations. Demand-driven policy instruments offer the possibility to overcome market failures and allow risk sharing between co-owners and investors...
project.objective: There is a clear gap in the adoption of paediatric healthcare innovations which continues to hinder the access to such innovations. Demand-driven policy instruments offer the possibility to overcome market failures and allow risk sharing between co-owners and investors. These include Public Procurement of Innovation (PPI) and Pre-Commercial Procurement (PCP), Value-Based Procurement (VBP), and Social Impact Bonds (SIBs). Such demand-driven funding instruments have the potential to reduce the adoption gap in paediatric healthcare. However, these innovative funding tools are rarely used to support paediatric innovation adoption. This limited adoption of demand-driven funding tools can be attributed to several barriers which are specific to paediatric healthcare, such as the perceived high-risk and complex nature of bringing paediatric innovations to market, fragmented regulatory pathways and market access, limited market demand (low numbers of patients) and perceived small impact. Additionally, there is poor awareness, knowledge and understanding of demand-driven tools, which results in their underutilisation. The i4KIDS-LEGACY project will create a holistic innovation action plan in paediatrics to ensure optimal implementation and utilisation of demand-driven innovation financing instruments to support the adoption of paediatric innovation in a coordinated manner across Europe. The project will: 1) Identify demand-driven financing instruments and mechanisms for paediatric health. 2) Collect data on the needs and challenges in the adoption of paediatric innovation. 3) Develop working groups to ideate solutions that address the needs and challenges identified. 4) Collaboratively build a European action plan to catalyse the use of demand-driven tools for the adoption of paediatric innovation solutions. 5)Promote cross-border adoption of paediatric innovations using financial instruments.
project.title: Accelerating Demand-Driven tools for pediatric innovation adoption - A collaborative roadmap for Europe
project.keywords: Paediatric health, adoption gap, co-creation, quadruple helix

article.title: Demand-driven innovation plan for paediatric healthcare

result.title: Open Science & Data Management Plan
result.description: Define how data will be generated, collected, handled, managed, and stored during and after the project. This will ensure that data handling meets all legal and IP requirements and that the benefits of the data can be maximised for internal or external future use.

result.title: Report on the co-design activities for the adoption of innovation mechanisms and financial instruments in paediatric health
result.description: co-design activities for supporting the suppliers of innovation

result.title: Communication and Dissemination Plan
result.description: The overall approach is to ensure that members promote communication and dissemination activities in a coordinated and easy manner. A communication toolkit with different templates for social media and other channels will be prepared. Strategy for internal communication within the consortium will be also set-up.

result.title: European action plan for sustainable paediatric innovation adoption mechanisms
result.description: We will prepare an action plan to address the needs, overcome the challenges, reduce the risks and financial burden that includes:1. The “demand-driven” paediatric ecosystem community created in WP2. This ecosystem will contribute to the execution and sustainability of the action plan and will have a role in the adoption of innovation in low, moderate and high innovation countries.2. Implementation of specific capacity building programmes for different stakeholders. Including programmes for helping innovation suppliers in the implementation of a demand-driven innovation adoption, co-designed by the stakeholders in Task 3.1 and 3.2. Also, capacitate health system and procurers in the implementation of the instruments, legal framework counselling,3. Actions for raising awareness and sharing the needs on the adoption of innovation in paediatrics to policy makers.

result.title: Europe Paediatric Innovation Adoption Situation and Analysis Report
result.description: The final objective will be to know the different mechanisms that the different European regions put at the disposal of their ecosystems, as well as the barriers and needs of the stakeholders involved in the development and adoption of paediatric solutions.Report summarising the current state-of-the-art of the paediatric innovation and adoption landscape in Europe and beyond, giving special focus on the depth of the paediatric innovation gap.

result.title: Demand-driven financing instruments and mechanisms in paediatric health Map and Database
result.description: creating a comprehensive and sustainable solution, the action plan will be designed to encourage the utilisation of these vehicles by diverse actors of the quadruple helix across the EU

result.title: Launch of Collaborative Strategic Plan
result.description: A final event will be held at the end of the project that will be used as the launch of the strategic plan

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 1 - Add4Kids (Accelerating Demand-Driven tools for pediatric innovation adoption - A collaborative roadmap for Europe)
result.teaser: ADD4KIDS addresses the gap in European pediatric healthcare innovation adoption, driven by barriers like complex regulatory pathways, limited market size, and high perceived risks. Demand-driven policy instruments such as Public Procurement of Innovation (PPI), Pre-Commercial...

category.title: Report Summary
category.description: Result: Publishable summary (FP7 SESAM) and Summary for publication (H2020 SyGMa)

result.title: White Paper on how to improve the adoption of meaningful innovation for paediatric patients
result.description: White Paper on the use of demand driven tools to improve the adoption of meaningful innovation for paediatric patients, carers and society. Will be published.

result.title: Report on the establishment of Solution Framework Generation
result.description: Through a comparative assessment of current programs and state-of-art out of the EU region, specific “success” criteria will be defined to inform the development of the solution framework.

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
